ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt how to research better and how to give a presentation on that research.
I learned a ton about the disinformation landscape in Europe and beyond, as well as how to apply research, communication and writing skills in a group setting.

Working with a team to develop an interdisciplinary capstone project that covered all our interests; interviewing leading scholars and policymakers; learnt the intricacies of disinformation tactics and campaigns in Europe and the Global South
From this course, I developed profound knowledge in the global disinformation sphere
Primarily leadership and teamwork skills - the capstone really can't come together with only once a week meetings, so a lot of organization had to be done behind the scenes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the travel, the group nature of the work

Weaknesses: I wish we had a little more reading/guidance earlier in the semester

There is a lot of flexibility and the capstone is entirely student-driven, which can be both a strength and a weakness depending on your work style - a bit more structure at the beginning of the course could be helpful. However, we had an incredible time traveling to Finland over break and it was one of the most unique academic experiences I've had at Yale - definitely travel if you get the chance - and the professor was incredibly supportive and open to feedback throughout.
Strength: Professor. He was great!! Always flexible to student wishes and direction. His list of contacts was extremely helpful and he fostered a great capstone community.

Strengths - the sky is the limit with the capstone. With all the funding and connections Jackson has to offer, you can really dream big. We went to Finland and had a great time. 

Weaknesses - 
It's so funny because the presentations feel like Yale kids think they have the answers to really pressing world problems... but we don't. 

We didn't have a client, and I feel that that was a really core part of the Capstone project. The professor had said that we were going to be working for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), but that was really just part of a competition for the DHS, which we ended up deciding not to do, because it could limit what we do with our capstone. 

Communication with higher ups in Jackson was really difficult - we didn't know how long our presentation had to be until 2 days before.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a GLBL Major requirement
Yes, definitely - it was a really rewarding experience to conclude our time in the major
Yes! If you are interested in learning about global disinformation.
It's required for the Global major, so you have to take it. But I'd say the most important thing is to pick your mentor wisely.
